apt install curl rsync build-essential

source ~/.cargo/env

crypto_call_justification: Pathvector relies on the Go standard library for cryptographic functions.
crypto_floss_justification: Pathvector relies on the Go standard library for cryptographic functions.
crypto_keylength_justification: The only cryptography built into Pathvector binaries is TLS for HTTPS connections to Pathvector Portal using the default TLS Go config (https://golang.org/src/crypto/tls/common.go)
crypto_working_justification: Pathvector relies on the Go standard library for cryptographic functions.
crypto_pfs_justification: Pathvector doesn't store keys and relies on the Go standard library for HTTPS.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Pathvector doesn't store cryptographic hashes of any kind.
crypto_random_justification: Pathvector relies on the Go standard library for cryptographic functions.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Pathvector doesn't rely on hash retrieval over insecure transports.

name: Akri
description:
Akri is A Kubernetes Resource Interface for the Edge. It removes the work of finding, using, and monitoring the availability of the IoT devices around Kubernetes clusters. it provides an abstraction layer for device usage, handling the dynamic appearance and disappearance of IoT devices on the Edge.

An operator simply applies an Akri Configuration to a cluster, specifying the Discovery Handler (most commonly a protocol) that should be used to discover the devices, and the pod that should be deployed upon discovery. Then Akri does the rest.

An operator can also allow multiple nodes to use an IoT device, thereby providing high availability in the case where a node goes offline. Furthermore, Akri will automatically create a Kubernetes service for each type of device, removing the need for an application to track the state of pods or nodes.

Simply put: you name it, Akri finds it, you use it.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/project-akri/akri/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://docs.akri.sh/
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All code changes (beyond documentation) lead to an increment of Akri's minor version and the building of containers for that version. Non-release containers can be publicly accessed with our development helm chart (`helm install akri akri-helm-charts/akri-dev`).
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: Each release has a git tag: https://github.com/project-akri/akri/tags
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/project-akri/akri/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: All Rust specific issues are captured via our security audit workflow which runs daily. If it finds a known Rust vulnerability (using `cargo-audit`), it creates an issue on Akri. Akri addresses these before releases. Other issues as they arise will be documented in the security tab on Github.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: There is not currently a published process, this will be fixed soon.
build_justification: Akri components can be built using its Makefile (https://github.com/project-akri/akri/blob/main/Makefile) and developer documentation (https://docs.akri.sh/development/development)
build_common_tools_justification: Akri components can be built using its Makefile (https://github.com/project-akri/akri/blob/main/Makefile) and developer documentation (https://docs.akri.sh/development/development). All required build tools are freely available and downloadable.
test_justification: Akri uses `cargo test` for testing Rust code and GitHub Actions for integration tests. The appropriate tests are automatically kicked off during PRs.
test_invocation_justification: Rust tests can be run with `cargo test`. This is documented in Akri's Contributor Guide: https://docs.akri.sh/community/contributing#how-do-i-get-started-developing.
test_most_justification: Akri has extensive unit testing of it's Rust code and runs integration tests for its demo debugEcho discovery handler. However, integration tests should be added (at least for releases) that test each of Akri's discovery handlers. Akri also does not have full unit test coverage of its sample brokers and apps as they are only for demo purposes.
test_policy_justification: Akri's pull request template urges tests to be added that can be run with `cargo test`.
tests_are_added_justification: Akri runs a code coverage workflow (using `cargo tarpaulin`) for each PR to ensure added code does not reduce Akri's overall test coverage.
tests_documented_added_justification: Akri's pull request template urges tests to be added that can be run with `cargo test`.
warnings_fixed_justification: Akri uses Rust tools (`cargo check` and `cargo fmt`) to ensure all code in pull requests is properly formatted before being merged.
static_analysis_justification: Rust static analysis tools are not common in the rust community and the language itself ensures complete memory control except in cases of explicitly labeled "unsafe" blocks. This project doesn't have any unsafe blocks in its direct code.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Rust is a memory safe language
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.

name: kernel
description: openEuler  openEuleropenEuler Linux
contribution_justification: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel/blob/kernel-4.19/Documentation/process/howto.rst
license_location_justification: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel/blob/kernel-4.19/COPYING
floss_license_justification: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel/blob/kernel-4.19/COPYING The GPL-2.0-or-later license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI). The GPL-2.0-or-later license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel/tree/kernel-4.19/Documentation
repo_public_justification: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel.git
repo_track_justification: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel.git
repo_distributed_justification: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel.git
tests_documented_added_justification: Not all new features are able to have automated tests added for them. But, for new syscalls, we do strongly recommend that new tests be added to the automated test suite to show that testing has happened, and to allow for regressions to be found over time.
warnings_strict_justification: Where ever practical, all warnings are fixed.
static_analysis_justification: Coverity and sparse and smatch and many other static code analysis tools are run on the kernel all the time.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: We use coverity and sparse and smatch and others for this.
dynamic_analysis_justification: https://01.org/lkp/documentation/0-day-test-service runs lots of these tools on all trees before release.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We use coverity and sparse and smatch and others for this
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Look at all of the wonderful BUG_ON() calls in the kernel (hint, you really don't want those to ever trigger, but they are there...
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: https://01.org/lkp/documentation/0-day-test-service The 0-day bot does testing of every commit before it is merged into the main repository.
hardening_justification: The Linux kernel self protection project develops hardening improvements for the Linux kernel; many of them have already been accepted into the Linux kernel mainline: http://kernsec.org/wiki/index.php/Kernel_Self_Protection_Project There are a number of hardening mechanisms in the Linux kernel, such as Linux kernel stack protection.
crypto_used_network_justification: The kernel implements network packets in general; applications running on top request or perform network communication. The kernel does implement IPSEC, which is used if requested. Otherwise, the user specifically requests or configures whatever network protocol is used.
crypto_tls12_justification: The kernel properly implements TLS if you are so crazy as to wish to use it from within kernelspace.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: The kernel properly implements TLS if you are so crazy as to wish to use it from within kernelspace.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: The kernel properly implements TLS if you are so crazy as to wish to use it from within kernelspace.
hardened_site_justification: https://github.com/openeuler-mirror/kernel // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.
installation_common_justification: Many third parties provide packages (e.g., .deb for apt-get, .rpm). It's also provided as an xz-compressed tarball. Since this is a kernel, installation is in general different than application software.
documentation_roadmap_justification: There is never a roadmap for the kernel, this type of thing is crazy for a project to try to determine. If you want to see what is coming, look at https://git.kernel.org/
documentation_quick_start_justification: A kernel is not a "quick start" type of thing. That being said, https://kernelnewbies.org does provide a lot of documentation for people getting involved in development.
internationalization_justification: A kernel does not need to have any locale at all.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel has full changelog history of all commits, see the "Reported-by:" tags for full attributions.
build_standard_variables_justification: All build environment variables are properly handled.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Configuration options allow for all debugging symbols to be retained in the built objects.
build_non_recursive_justification: No recursion in the build system when there are cross-dependencies in the subdirectories.
build_repeatable_justification: The kernel meets the reproducible build requirements.
installation_standard_variables_justific: The kernel install process is standard on all distros as there is a distro-specific include script which always will work properly.
installation_development_quick_justifica: All distros usually have a 'kernel-developer' meta-package option to automatically install needed dependancies to build the project.
external_dependencies_justification: The kernel has no external dependencies.
dependency_monitoring_justification: The kernel has no external dependencies.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: The kernel has no external dependencies.
interfaces_current_justification: The kernel has no external dependencies.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: The 0-day bot runs on each commit in almost all maintainers trees before they are merged into Linus's tree.
regression_tests_added50_justification: It is impossible to create automated regression tests for even a small percentage of the bugs found in the kernel. But, people are actively working on this, and we do have a very large test suite that includes checks for almost all major CVEs that can be tested for.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: Code coverage is a horrible metric. See above for the discussion about our automated regression tests.
test_policy_mandated_justification: Not all kernel functionality can be tested with an automated test suite. That being said, we do have a huge test suite for almost all major functionality that is run all the time on all maintainer's branches to ensure no regressions happen.
implement_secure_design_justification: The kernel implements "known secure design" principles.
input_validation_justification: "All input is evil" is the mantra the kernel attempts to follow. We have automated testing for following userspace data into the kernel and when it is validated properly.
version_tags_signed_justification: All tags for kernel releases are properly signed.
test_statement_coverage90_justification:
There is no such tool that can provide this.

And code coverage is not an indication of code quality
test_branch_coverage80_justification: No such tool can provide this.
security_review_justification: Lots of people audit the kernel all the time for these types of issues.
assurance_case_justification: The kernel's security requirements are constantly tested and probed by everyone in the world. When problems are found, they are resolved as quickly as possible as described in our security bugs reporting documentation: https://gitee.com/openeuler/kernel/blob/kernel-4.19/Documentation/admin-guide/security-bugs.rst

warnings_justification:
Compiler flags set at https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri/blob/main/ext/nokogiri/extconf.rb#L597-L612

We also run the entire test suite under valgrind, see https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri/blob/main/.github/workflows/ci.yml#L98 for one instance of a Valgrind run (there are others)
warnings_fixed_justification: See https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri/pull/2303 for an example of work done to clean up warnings.
warnings_strict_justification: We've iterated on the set of flags that are relevant and meaningful.
know_secure_design_justification: Mike Dalessio and Aaron Patterson have both received extensive security training by our employers.
know_common_errors_justification: Mike Dalessio and Aaron Patterson have both received extensive security training by our employers.
delivery_mitm_justification: Recent releases have been accompanied by SHA256 checksums published on the github release page. See, for example, https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri/releases/tag/v1.12.5
delivery_unsigned_justification: Github enforces HTTP on the releases page, see for example https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri/releases/tag/v1.12.5
static_analysis_justification: Rubocop is used for static analysis of security issues.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Rubocop is used for static analysis of security issues.
static_analysis_often_justification: Rubocop runs on every commit pushed to default branch and on every PR; as well as running a minimum of once a week on a timer.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: libxml2, the underlying C library, receives extensive fuzz testing.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: libxml2, the underlying C library, receives extensive fuzz testing.
general_comments: Nokogiri is a long-running and actively maintained project, see https://www.ruby-toolbox.com/projects/nokogiri for objective statistics.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Thorough CI suite runs on every pull request and push to default branch: https://github.com/sparklemotion/nokogiri/actions
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: Docs are at https://nokogiri.org/ and issues and merge requests can be submitted in English via github.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
